title-group.article-title: Subpolitics and Democracy: The Role of New Media in the 2011 General Elections in Singapore

contrib.aff: T.T. Sreekumar, Associate Professor, Mudra Institute of Communications, Ahmedabad (MICA), India. E-mail: sreekumar@micamail.in
Shobha Vadrevu, Doctoral Candidate, Department of Communications & New Media, Faculty of Arts & Social Sciences, National University of Singapore, Singapore. E-mail: shobha.vadrevu@nus.edu.sg

abstract.p: Making use of the recent STS focus on the idea of subpolitics, the study seeks to understand the limited yet important implications of the rise of the political twitterati1 for liberal democracy in Singapore. The phenomenon marks a significant development not in terms of facilitating mass upheavals or radical reforms as elsewhere in the world, but in terms of contributing towards the construction of counter narratives to the historically articulated and previously uncontested discourses of progress, efficiency, productivity and success that in part have legitimated the political establishment in Singapore. By critiquing the regime’s myriad narratives of accomplishments and constructing subversive counter narratives through ‘series tweets’ that were infused with wit, sarcasm, parody and satire, the political twitterati in Singapore has expanded the vistas of democratic participation while remaining loyal to the country’s non-Western liberal democratic framework.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: THE RELEVANCE OF subpolitics is beginning to be widely recognised in the field of STS. A paper by de Vries (2007) highlights the value of the subpolitical (Bakardjieva, 2009; Beck, 1997; Linde and Lindgren, 2010) in examining expert influence in technological decisions. Building on the work of Collins and Evans (2002) who express concern that a democracy may not be able to afford an infinite amount of subpolitics, de Vries argues that the scope of the subpolitical needs to be delineated before it can be of any theoretical value for STS. Initially arguing that the modern view of democratic engagement is instrumental in nature and viewing stakeholders in the decision-making process as ‘mini kings’, de Vries suggests that this is akin to poiesis in the Aristotelian framework. Poiesis, however, according to de Vries, does not help us to understand the way in which contributions outside of the explicitly political arena have a qualitative impact on political decisions. He suggests that Aristotle’s idea of praxis might come closer to explaining this phenomenon, dealing as it does with the way in which actions and discourse combine to create an object which is an end in itself, rather than a means to an end. Focusing on praxis allows us to explain how the non-political moves into the political and thus has an indirect impact on democracy.

In this article, we take up this particular aspect of subpolitics retaining some of its meaning derived from the field of STS and incorporating de Vries’ refinement through the lens of praxis and apply it to political engagement by influential actors on a social media platform at the time of a watershed General Election in Singapore. While deterministic statements about the role of social media in influencing election results in Singapore are unproductive, we argue, through our analysis, that the use of the platform in particular ways has larger implications for the future of democracy in Singapore. Our article seeks to explain the impact of a subpolitical phenomenon on the reconfiguring of politics in Singapore. De Vries frames current STS discourse on the subpolitical as a continuation of a limited view of democratic politics and he introduces the Aristotelian framework in order to highlight the mechanisms by which the subpolitical evolves so that what counts as subpolitical can be carefully defined. Through our empirical case study, we further the argument that subpolitics needs closer examination in technological societies. In doing so, we expand the scope of STS studies beyond the relationship between technical decisions taken by a minority and larger democratic processes; by studying a new media phenomenon that has a particular kind of legitimacy of its own.

We posit that the evolution of a political twitterati that contributes to political thought may be analogous to the development of a technical expert discourse that contributes to technological decision making in the public sphere. The larger democratic election process may not have been directly affected by the twitterati’s contributions, but at the same time there was an organic link that qualitatively transformed the democratic process because the medium provided a certain kind of critique of the system which trickled down to the larger democratic process. The ‘object’ thus constituted was the quality of democracy in Singapore.

In his compelling commentary on the down side of Iran’s over glorified ‘Twitter revolution’ Morozov (2009a, p. 12) argues that something like a ‘Twitter revolution is only possible in a regime where the state apparatus is completely ignorant of the Internet and has no virtual presence of its own’. In his view, most authoritarian states eagerly exploit cyberspace ‘for their own strategic purposes’(Ibid) and specifically in Iran’s case, both Twitter and Facebook provided Iran’s secret services ideal platforms for gathering intelligence about political activists and their intimate connections. According to him, ‘(O)nce regimes used torture to get this kind of data; now it’s freely available on Facebook’ (Ibid). Drawing on Morozov (2009a, 2011), Christensen (2011, p. 234) has pointed out that ‘(t)he very terms “Twitter Revolution” (Iran) and “Facebook Revolution” (Egypt) have now been called into question as overly techno-deterministic and techno-utopian’ since such approaches ignore the use of social media by authoritarian regimes for the purposes of surveillance and repression. Further discussions on the Iranian case have provided caveats that help move beyond positions with technological deterministic overtones hinging on cyber-utopianism and state dystopianism (Erlich, 2009; Rahimi, 2011). Nevertheless, Rheingold’s (2002) predictions of a new wave of activism that makes use of powerful online networks based on synergetic connections to organise people, share information and make decisions through collective intelligence even under conditions of anonymity (Warlaumont, 2010) still appeal to many scholars and activists.2

This article, based on tweets and re-tweets (RTs) captured just before and after the May 2011 General Elections in Singapore, seeks to explore the role of twitterati in the politicisation of public debate, with specific focus on the small state of Singapore. Singapore, paradoxically, is as well known for its highly wired population as it is for its comparably lower level of online political participation (Baber, 2003; Banerjee and Yeo, 2003; George, 2006; Ho, Baber and Khondker, 2002; Rodan, 2003). In the May 2011 General Election to the Singapore Parliament, one of the opposition parties, Workers Party (WP), for the first time substantially increased representation in parliament by winning a group constituency of five legislatures triggering debates on the role of social media in realising the surprise win.3

The process of gradual democratisation of political engagement in Singapore leading to the growth of a Singaporean public on social media was fuelled by the affordances of the social media platforms that urge users onto a learning curve of wider participation. The strategic use of these affordances by key players involved a partial critique of government institutions, practices and procedures, creating a new social space of active political engagement unavailable in Singapore’s mainstream media. Based on the analysis of representative series tweets, we argue that the phenomenon marks a significant development not in terms of facilitating mass upheavals or radical reforms as elsewhere in the world, but in terms of contributing towards the construction of counter narratives to the historically articulated and previously uncontested discourses of progress, efficiency, productivity and success that in part have legitimated the political establishment in Singapore. By critiquing the regime’s myriad narratives of accomplishments and constructing subversive counter narratives through ‘series tweets’ that were infused with wit, sarcasm, parody and satire, the political twitterati in Singapore attempted to challenge the post-colonial consensus on Singapore as ‘an intelligent island’ (Mahizhnan, 2000). It may be noted that while hegemonic discourse on administrative efficiency has met serious challenges elsewhere in post developmental Asia during the times of crises such as the outbreak of bird flu, SARS etc. (Ku, 2001), such efforts to delegitimise the ruling establishment had been completely absent in Singapore. The new Singaporean public, composed of a previously quiescent citizenry, has begun to discover the possibilities of online political engagement and critique on a wider scale. The phenomenon provides an opportunity to analyse an alternative perspective on social networking activism based on liberal values and a belief in gradual change, rather than looking at them as inevitable harbingers of political revolutions or as mere constructions of the global corporate media.

sec.title: Political Engagement and the Internet in Singapore
sec.p: Singapore has been noted for its early successes in focusing on the extensive use of information technology for economic growth and governance (Kuo and Low, 2001; Mahizhnan, 2000; Rodan, 2003) in striking contrast to the experience of most other countries in developing Asia (Sreekumar, 2011; Sreekumar and Rivera-Sanchez, 2008). Nevertheless, online political participation in Singapore had not kept pace with the rapid development of infrastructure due to legal restrictions and resource constraints faced by opposition parties (Kluver, 2004). The advent of the Internet in the middle of the 1990s did not have any extensive influence during the General Elections in 1996, 2001 and 2006 although its role in building alternatives to mainstream media to publish oppositional views and opinions began to attract public attention (George, 2010; Gomez, 2002). On the contrary, the 2011 General Election was widely perceived as a turning point in terms of the extensive use of the Internet for political participation not only by oppositional parties but also by ordinary citizens as well as interest groups (Lim, 2011, p. 5).

The phenomenal change in terms of the unprecedented influence of the Internet in the Singapore General Election 2011, was facilitated by three major developments namely, the emergence of new social media such as Facebook and Twitter, wide adoption of mobile Internet devices such as smartphones and liberalisation of governmental regulations on the use of the Internet for online campaigning (George, 2011, p. 148). The speed and reach of the Internet made political awareness trickle down to Singapore-focused websites and online discussion groups, forming a nucleus around which discussion could grow (Gomez, 2005). Political activity was gradually incorporated into new ways of articulating identity online, reinforcing a gradual process of Internet acculturation already under way for more than a decade (George, 2005; Soon and Cho, 2011; Warschauer, 2001). Rodan (2003, p. 519) has pointed out that even in the early days of the diffusion of the Singaporean Internet, information control faced technical challenges in ways that tested the effectiveness of established mechanisms in Singapore.

In striking contrast to previous elections, during the lead-up to the May 2011 General Elections, online activity across blogs, social media platforms and discussion boards registered a conspicuous increase (George, 2011; Soo, 2011). Despite survey evidence that local television news coverage and newspapers had a greater influence on voters, the overall impression was of an online world abuzz with information and opinions that in prior elections had been more muted (R. Tham, 2011). The 2006 General Elections also had been noted for being an ‘Internet election’, with blog posts carrying reports (for example about massive attendance at the election rallies of opposition parties) that seemed to be deliberately left out of the mainstream media (Ibrahim, 2009). With the 2011 Elections, however, social media platforms allowed even more people to add their voices to the stream of online content. Overwhelmingly, there was a sense that only anti-government and anti-ruling party voices were able to make themselves heard online and there were serious doubts about the veracity of much of the anti-Establishment information that spread through social networking sites.4 Following the Election, an entrepreneur and author who wrote a Facebook note in defence of the ruling party, the People’s Action Party (PAP), expressed the sentiment with irony and bewilderment:
When did this happen? It used to be that if you spoke up against the PAP, you feared for your life. But now online sentiment for the PAP has turned so overwhelmingly negative that I’m afraid to post this! (Moh, 2011)

As R. Tham (2011) observed, this was not an isolated experience:
Anti-PAP sentiments on Facebook and Twitter had reached such incredible heights that people who ‘dared to criticise the opposition’ or advocate the capabilities of the PAP, would be ostracised by the online community…popular local blogger Wendy Cheng, a.k.a. Xiaxue, was ‘flamed’ by the online community after she had expressed support for the PAP on her online blog. The online resentment towards her was so intense that advertisers had to pull their ads from her blog in order to avoid any potential backlash.

While the post-election critiques of the role, influence, bias and prejudice of social media-based political discourses in Singapore point to an unprecedented consolidation of oppositional politics in social media, there has been no serious discussion on the nature and content of this expanded democratic participation. Most political blogs in Singapore that are overtly critical of the government are still anonymous—posting links to them on Twitter or Facebook does not carry as much responsibility as writing them. What seems to be on the public agenda, far from a desire to overthrow the state, appears to be a liberalising of the ‘illiberal democracy’ (Zakaria, 2004). The ease of sharing on Twitter and the informal tone that is a common discursive feature which lowers barriers to access may be seen as building up towards a form of democratic media activism (Carroll and Hackett, 2006), although currently lacking in the element of collective action that normally defines such activism. In the Singapore case, social media may be seen as a mechanism that supports gradual democratic development as citizens get inducted into democratic practices of emerging publics. It may also be seen as part of a larger move towards democracy that has its roots outside of the nation state, even while it is used to deal with decidedly local issues.

Tweeting and re-tweeting are recognised as a conversational practice and can be understood as a process of negotiating authorship, attribution and communicative fidelity (boyd et al., 2010). The practice of re-tweeting is a complex one, not least because it can be done in so many ways. Given the right conditions, Twitter can be a way of expressing solidarity with a cause in a situation where such expressions lack offline outlets. The rise of a political twitterati in Singapore via a platform that spans a wider network opens up the possibility of a discussion of publics that takes into account the role of the network in cultivating the public, as well as the potential of the network for further nurturing this public as it seeks gradual democratic change. In the next section a study is described that examines the evolution of a Singaporean public on Twitter, with a view to exploring the role of the platform in the gradual induction of citizens into democratic modes of engagement, leading to the suggestion that this process of induction falls squarely within the realm of the subpolitical.

sec.title: The Emergence of the Political Twitterati in Singapore
sec.p: Scholars analysing social media with a focus on Twitter have used varying methodologies (Hargittai and Litt, 2011; Lassen and Brown, 2011; Lingdren and Lundstrom, 2011; Marwick and boyd, 2011; Small, 2011; Yardi and boyd, 2010). The approaches range from conventional qualitative/quantitative methods using primary/secondary data offline, to using software to retrieve tweets utilising interfaces available through Twitter’s Application Programming Interface (API). Twitter provides an API to access data, which allows programmers to systematise the interaction with the data pool. A call on ‘User timeline’ (Documentation page: http://dev.twitter.com/doc/get/statuses/user_timeline), provides the 100 most recent tweets of any Twitter handle. Access to older tweets is provided by increasing page number which can be raised to a maximum value of 15. Similarly, in the case of hashtags (Documentation page: http://dev.twitter.com/doc/get/search), a call can provide access to the 100 most recent results. As in the case of tweets, by increasing page number older results for hashtags can also be accessed. However, unlike in the case of tweets, the maximum number is limited by time. We can access only one week’s data irrespective of how many results we have. The results appear in a format called JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) (selected because it is simple to parse). In our case, the programme was written in java programming language to send the requests, download the data and write into another file, which was copied to an Excel file for coding. The three basic steps in our data collection may be summarised as follows: (a) download tweets in JSON format based on API calls, (b) parse to get the details, store them in a database and (c) copy required fields to Excel.5

The methodology was sufficient for our purpose of identifying important tweeters and hashtags that were closely relevant to our focus of research. Based on this method, we collected and analysed data in two streams, one using general quantitative data from thirteen key Twitter accounts and the other using two qualitative case studies. Thirteen Twitter accounts were identified that were actively producing socio-political tweets relating to Singapore prior to the General Elections. While not all of these accounts were solely dedicated to political tweets, they were among the top few that emerged when the search term ‘Singapore’ was entered in the Twitter search bar.6 The tweets of the thirteen accounts at two points in time (17 March 2011 and 25 May 2011) were randomly retrieved using the above mentioned programme that tapped on Twitter’s API, in the four-month period (February, March, April and May 2011) when we were closely following political developments in social media in Singapore as part of this research. The dates neither signify days with any particular acceleration of tweets nor were they too close to the polling date. Singapore’s 16th parliamentary General Election was held on 7 May 2011 with the date of nomination falling on 27 April 2011. We noticed in early March the increase in election-related tweets in Singapore and mid-March appeared to be an ideal time point to catch this early interest. Although the political twitterati continued to be active after the election, by the end of May 2011, their enthusiasm was slowly shifting to the upcoming Presidential Election and we decided to capture the post-election data on May 25 before the subsequent drift. Table 1 presents details of the thirteen accounts as provided on their respective profile pages. The descriptions provide a broad view of the various roles played by these accounts and hint at the motivations of the accounts with regard to influencing the socio-political sphere in Singapore. Given the ease of setting up and deleting Twitter accounts, we make no claims about the current activities and influence of the accounts in our data set. Rather, we present their profiles as a case study from a significant time period, with data representing their influence, motivation and impact at the time of collection.

sec.p: The total number of tweets for each account was calculated, as was the total number of re-tweets. The total number of tweets includes mentions, replies and re-tweets in a variety of forms. It must be noted that the Twitter API does not allow more than 3,000-plus tweets at a time and that even this number is not consistently applied each time. However the total number of Tweets obtained does mirror to some extent the relative volume of tweets across the different accounts. Re-tweets are recognised as a measure of the influence of a Twitter account as well as a way of engaging in the conversation without having to compose a tweet that may not be valued as highly. Re-tweets are problematic in their own way, because re-tweeting can be done in many ways, not all of which are captured by the API. However across all the accounts, re-tweet count was calculated in the same manner—via the API and not taking into account tweets that quoted the original tweet with the RT tag in front of them, or simply quoted the tweet without the tag. The number of re-tweets to tweets was then calculated as a ratio, in order to identify the most influential Twitter accounts. The figures from the first data set, downloaded on the 17 March 2011, are presented in the form of a graph in Figure 1 that clearly shows the distribution of influence in the form of re-tweet ratio.

The figures from the second data set, downloaded on 25 May 2011, are presented in the graph in Figure 2 showing the distribution of the re-tweet ratios for these accounts. It may be noted that Figure 2 shows George Yeo, the defeated PAP candidate and Foreign Affairs Minister in the incumbent Cabinet as having the highest re-tweet figures followed by Fake_PMLee and mrbrown. We consider this an aberration since he could have been riding a sympathy wave in the wake of his defeat—even the opposition parties projected him as future President of Singapore during the campaign (Tan, 2011, pp. 61–62)—which is corroborated by aFigure 3 showing the combined picture for the two data sets. From Figures 1 and 3, the top two accounts that emerged were Fake_PMLee (with a ratio of 20.22 re-tweets for every tweet) and mrbrown (with a ratio of 12.45 re-tweets for every tweet). These accounts are the ones we have thematically coded and analysed in detail as qualitative case studies and in an exploration of the manner in which they wielded their influence via their tweets.

sec.p: A quick note on a few other critical participants with an explicit interest in political reforms in Singapore will be in order. Accounts such as tocsg, FakeSTcom, SGnews and sgelection took on roles that exploited the perceived gaps left by the lack of coverage of alternative views in the mainstream media. The first is managed by a political website known as The Online Citizen, which aims to provide balanced coverage of alternative viewpoints and stimulate discussion about public issues. Most of the tweets from this account link to posts on the parent site. The account is significant because the parent site was recently gazetted by the government as a political association, an acknowledgement of the influential power of the site in the public sphere. SGnews and sgelection are news aggregating accounts, posting links to news articles in mainstream media as well as blogs and alternative sites. In this way, they raise the status of citizen journalists to that of the mainstream media, which is seen as a mouthpiece of the government. FakeSTcom posts links to articles in the Straits Times, Singapore’s main newspaper, but adds witty and sarcastic comments that ridicule the perceived lack of independence, intelligence and integrity of those who run the newspaper. These 3 accounts—along with temasekreview (another account linked to a parent site like tocsg) and PAPLightning—confront the lack of balance in mainstream media, the tight control of the government and the contentious issues that receive little public debate. The account entitled yourSDP belongs to the Singapore Democratic Party, an opposition party.

sec.title: Popular Twitter Handles and Critical Counter Narratives
sec.p: This section takes a look at the nature of the communication model that the political twitterati in Singapore has developed based on the analysis of selected series and individual tweets by the two most popular Twitter handles in Singapore. The influence of these critical accounts has to be seen against the backdrop of accounts that appear strongly aligned with government policies which receive very low re-tweet counts, making tweeting itself into a subpolitics with an autonomy of its own. Given that Twitter allows for the exploitation of structural gaps and that alternative voices unrepresented in the mainstream media have utilised this affordance, supporters of the government probably do not feel the need to coalesce around these nodes. More significant is the low re-tweet count for accounts such as tocsg and temasekreview, which are established alternative voices online. An analysis of the tweets of Fake_PMLee (an account parodying the Prime Minister of Singapore) and mrbrown (an account run by a well-known blogger and socio-political commentator in Singapore) shows that there are particular features that lead to a high re-tweet count and to a greater observable influence in general. When viewed in this regard, it can be seen that temasekreview, tocsg and other accounts with low re-tweet count do not manifest these features in their tweets. Especially of interest are tweets that came in series focusing on a particular topic, because these indicate a commitment to give lengthy consideration to the topic that goes beyond a single tweet, as well as confidence that followers will stay engaged throughout the series of tweets and even contribute to them.

Both Fake_PMLee and mrbrown are generally critical of the government and its institutions (this includes the mainstream media). What is immediately observable, however, is the comicality with which this critique is conveyed. For example, in a series of tweets grouped around the hashtag #SG_productivity (a reference to the government’s call for increased productivity among the workforce in Singapore), Fake_PMLee tapped on the notion of productivity and turned it towards how the government functions, as seen through the eyes of his persona, the Prime Minister:
#SG_productivity: MSM to publish govt press releases as Editorial. Journalists expand competency by reportg on rapes in M’sia.
Suggestion to limit parliamentary debates to 140 characters. Reduce the debates from days to hours. #SG_productivity
When you launched enough defamation lawsuits, you prepare templates. #SG_productivity
When you accept new citizens who love your policies in time for election. #SG_productivity

The first tweet is a commentary on the mainstream media (MSM) and its control by the government. As a result, local events and issues tend to be covered less critically than those of other countries. Most articles on local issues tend to read like educational missives, in line with the way in which the role and responsibility of the press is viewed by the government. Fake_PMLee’s suggestion to increase productivity by abandoning the farce of press freedom and freeing up reporters to critique other countries by directly publishing government press releases is thus a pithy comment on press freedom, state control, low quality of journalism and the productivity rhetoric. The second tweet references a suggestion made in parliament to cut down on the time allotted for each speech and points to the futility of debate in a context where decisions are made based on efficiency and control rather than consultation and consensus. The third tweet is especially sharp and makes reference to the PAP’s practice of bringing defamation suits against what they claim as unsubstantiated allegations. The idea of developing a template as an efficiency measure pokes fun not only at the use of defamation suits as an instrument of control, but at the technocratic paradigm within which the government operates. The last tweet above mentions the debate on the sudden influx of new citizens before the General Elections. While the government explained this in terms of economic necessity, the explanation was not one that was widely accepted and in fact became an election issue that cost the PAP some votes. This tweet expands the productivity theme even further into the sphere of instrumentality and hints at the idea that the PAP will do whatever needs to be done to ensure that its goals are met. In fact another tweet on the topic by Fake_PMLee was re-tweeted 24 times, showing that it resonated with his followers:
#SGporeans, don’t fret. At current rate, the early PRC & Indian immigrants will soon complain abt our open immigration policy. #NDRsg

The reference is made to new immigrants from India and China (the two main source countries in the present wave of immigration, but also two of the four major ethnic groups in Singapore), pointing to the rapidity with which they are being brought in and provided citizenship. That immigrants who themselves benefited only recently from an open immigration policy could turn around and criticise it for being too open to the next wave sounds enormously ironic. This critique of government policy couched in wit and sarcasm is a quality of the tweets that get frequently re-tweeted.

mrbrown’s tweets show the same tendency towards satirical critique. For example, during the Prime Minister’s National Day Rally speech in 2010, mrbrown tweeted the following:
Canada welcomes immigrants, so Microsoft hires talent there. Canada, as we all know, is the same size as Singapore. #ndrsg
I tell you what. Here is $9,000, I put into the government’s CPF account, then we forget about the National Service. Deal? #ndrsg
(link provided) Best paid political leader in the world tells his people to lower wage expectations. #ndrsg

The speech was delivered at a time when immigration was a contentious issue and opposition parties were expressing dissatisfaction with government policy that encouraged immigration based on economic exigency. The example of Canada’s policy of open immigration encouraging Microsoft to hire talent there is met here with witty cynicism and Singapore’s small size is alluded to as a way of deriding the comparison. It reflects the general objection to increasingly overcrowded conditions and a perception that infrastructure cannot cope with a large influx of immigrants. The second tweet is with reference to the government’s pay-out of S$9,000 to citizens who have completed their compulsory two-and-a-half-year stint in the army. Widely perceived as a way of reducing the tension over the issue—which again pitted new citizens and permanent residents who don’t have to serve National Service if they are past a certain age against existing citizens who cannot avoid it—the monetary reward is mocked by mrbrown as being insufficient compensation. Instead, he jokes, he will pay it to the government so that he does not have to serve the time in the army. The third tweet references the high salaries that ministers in Singapore receive, another contentious issue among the population. Here mrbrown contrasts the salary of the Prime Minister with the content of the speech where Singaporeans are told that they must be prepared to make do with less in challenging economic times. The wit in the construction of the tweet reinforces the simple yet stinging critique—not quite directly accusing the government of hypocrisy and yet alluding to it in an unmistakable way.

Fake_PMLee tweets as soon as any issue comes up, such as the Youth Olympic Games (YOG), the floods in the central shopping district of Orchard Road or the elections. This timeliness resonates with his followers and he is re-tweeted very quickly by many of them. For example, the following tweets were posted when the Youth Olympic Games coincided with heavy rain and floods. Both the games and the floods were contentious issues, the former because of multiple hitches and overspending and the latter because they were later proven to have been due to structural deficiencies and yet the authorities initially denied responsibility. Combining the two issues—the efficiency of the city state in holding a major event like YOG and the cracks in the credibility of the efficiency paradigm reflected in the flooding of Orchard Road—Fake_PMLee posted:
Because of #SGflood, the following #YOG games will be tweaked: Trialthlon will see the Swim segment take place in Orchard Road.
Because of #SGflood, the following #YOG games will be tweaked: Equestrian will see the horse changed to hippopotamus.
Because of #SGflood, the following #YOG games will be tweaked: Wrestling will now be Mud Wrestling.
Because of #SGflood, the following #YOG games will be tweaked: Swimming becomes Hurdles-Swimming; floating cars will be the hurdles.
Because of #SGflood, the following #YOG games will be tweaked: Football becomes Water Polo.

Unlike news-aggregating accounts that merely post links to articles, accounts of organisations that report on their events, or even alternative news accounts that link and report but do not generally initiate or take part in conversations on Twitter, Fake_PMLee and mrbrown both actively engage their followers through mentions, replies, sharing links with their own related comments attached (as opposed to leaving the link to stand on its own), re-tweeting and quoting tweets. The personal involvement creates a situation whereby their strong influence percolates down to smaller individual accounts—not just in terms of their tweets being re-tweeted, but also in terms of drawing more people into the conversation. An example of active engagement is the way in which mrbrown devises hashtags and re-tweets some of the tweets that contain them:
#smgohsaysdontcomplaintoomuch RT @tengkuzahirah: SBS should do something about the frequency of feeder buses in the am.
#smgohsaysdontcomplaintoomuch RT @Cherubie: It’s only Tuesday! Argh!

The hashtag here refers to a speech made by a senior minister encouraging Singaporeans not to complain too much and to accept certain realities of life. Subtly critiqued by mrbrown in a video he created and posted on his blog, the comment was turned into a hashtag ‘#smgohsaysdontcomplaintoomuch’ (expanded to mean ‘Senior Minister Goh says don’t complain too much’) that was then creatively applied to a wide range of tweets. Any sort of complaint was tagged with the hashtag and re-tweeted, with the effect that his timeline contained a series of tweets reframed as political commentary (however indirect), that could have the outcome of gradually socialising his followers into making connections, politicising ideas and critiquing established practices, traditions and norms.

One of the central aspects of the ‘series tweets’ is that they construct narratives which resemble storytelling. Using the technique of ‘series tweets’ these two prominent accounts attempt to create a set of alternative narratives and a shared field of political experience to provide legitimacy to the counter narratives which challenge the carefully constructed Singaporean stories of progress, economic success, productivity and efficiency. On the one hand, it is clear that the political twitterati did not aim to generate mass political mobilisation or become instrumental in triggering massive protests as seen in several other parts of the world where affordances of the platform, ostensibly, helped shape large social and political movements for democracy. Nor did they associate directly with any particular opposition party or subpolitical movement within the civil society to create alliances that have a potential to exert extra-parliamentary coercion for democratic reforms. However, the absence of such explicit political manoeuvring does not make the contribution of political twitterati in Singapore inconsequential. The substantive nature of the intervention is brought out by the specific accomplishment of successfully challenging the official narratives and ‘moral claims (that were) commonly accepted by Singaporeans, including members of opposition parties’ (Chua, 1994, p. 657).

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: The political engagements of the Singaporean twitterati appear to be similar to what Beck (1997) calls subpolitics with traces of what Bakardjieva (2009) has identified as a deeper level of political engagement called subactivism. While the ‘organised and/or publicly traceable initiatives of social movements and individuals finding themselves in strategic points of the social system’ (ibid., p. 96) are counted as subpolitics, Bakardjieva’s approach focuses on ‘small-scale, often individual decisions and actions that have either a political or ethical frame of reference (or both) and remain submerged in everyday life’ (ibid.). Bakardjieva highlights the potential for subactivism to be mobilised by trigger events and transformed into overt public activism and argues that subactivism ‘is that essential bedrock against which individual citizens’ capacity for participation in subpolitics or in the formal political institutions of the public world is shaped and nurtured’ (Bakardjieva, 2009, p. 96).

In this study, we have highlighted the importance and influence of subpolitics as an autonomous process without teleological implications. This is particularly striking when transposed against the specific history of democratic reforms in Singapore. Chua (1994, p. 655) had noted that there are conceptual and substantive difficulties in placing Singapore in the democratisation debate as ‘a highly stable polity which many critics continue to characterise as an “authoritarian regime”’. He argued that the perception that this authoritarian regime was ‘popularly elected, financially uncorrupt, manages the economy well, has improved the population’s standard of living and governs through due parliamentary process, all with a dash of self-sacrifice on the part of its leaders and members, adds up to a very powerful set of legitimatizing elements’ (ibid., p. 657). Our study shows that the political twitterati in Singapore has systematically taken on this carefully articulated discourse of efficiency and success. The popular Twitter handles have constructed counter images through tweets that are infused with wit, sarcasm, parody and satire, that are generative of a powerful mode of subpolitics. This new political engagement links up organically neither with opposition parties nor any particular political strata within the civil society in Singapore.

De Vries (2007) puts forward the argument that more attention needs to be given to the nature of the political in considerations of the subpolitical. His invocation of the Aristotelian framework, with its explication of the more instrumental poiesis and the more metadiscursive praxis, has value for the consideration of the future of democracy in Singapore. This is especially so in light of arguments about coercion and control. Viewing the subpolitical through the lens of praxis allows for the suggestion that a culture of democratic discourse, as seeded by action such as that of the twitterati, may have more long-term and less overt effects. Indeed, the Singapore state’s response to the emergence of the new media-based Singaporean public is characterised by democratic counter critique and political engagement. The belief that the state’s approach to new media will be one that essentially encompasses strategic moves of ‘embracing electronic media but suppressing civil society’ and of ‘preventing the emergence of organised social and political forces that could lead to a genuine civil society’ (Rodan, 2003, p. 503), seems unfounded.

The identification of thirteen Twitter accounts, ten of which made use of a structural gap in the wider socio-political context and took up the enabling features of the Twitter platform to reach a relevant audience, allow a claim to be made about the emergence of a Singaporean public on Twitter. While the extent of influence of all thirteen accounts is not equal, their very presence stimulates political engagement by others on Twitter, even if only through re-tweeting. However re-tweeting is not an insignificant activity. It carries information further and draws more people into the conversation. A case study of two highly influential Twitter accounts shows that effective use is being made of Twitter’s affordances to persuasively engage in commentary at an intensity that would not be possible in any other sphere, online or offline. In 140 characters at a time, capitalising on Twitter’s affordances to satirically critique the government, ensure timeliness and appropriateness and actively engage their followers, they have drawn around them a network that enthusiastically passes on their cleverly crafted tweets.

Tweets generated immediately prior to the General Election in May 2011, along with posts on Facebook in the same time period, were cited widely as major reasons for the opposition winning an unprecedented six seats in Parliament. Subsequent commentaries in the state-mediated press had also given a high level of coverage to the role of social media and the Prime Minister acknowledged the prominence of this role in his speech to the nation on National Day. Nevertheless, this unprecedented increase in political participation through social media did not lead to any radical changes in the political system in Singapore. The PAP retained their majoritarian dominance and all the contentious policies which had been hotly debated at opposition rallies prior to the Elections remained in place after the event, although with promises that they would be looked into, bearing in mind the pragmatic need for survival in a competitive economy. There was no collective action that arose out of the discourse of political engagement on social media and other online sites. Hong Lim Park was in no way turning into Tahrir Square.7

Early scholarly work on electronic democracy has very perceptively captured the problems of over-glorification of the potentials of new media technology for democratic participation (Friedland, 1996; Sawhney, 1996). Friedland (1996, p. 187) identifies three pertinent perspectives: first, he points to the threat that growth of information inequality poses for broad democratic participation. Second, he brings out the dangers of state and corporate engagement in electronic surveillance of civil society. Third, he highlights how new forms of citizenship and public life are both enabled by new technology and restricted by market power and surveillance. In line with these early critiques of electronic democracy we have argued that Singaporeans on Twitter have learned to use the affordances of the platform and are being inducted into a mode of communication that the platform has made possible while emphasising the need for creating fields of shared experiences for the sustenance of successful democratic participation. At the same time, we caution against any suggestion of a ground breaking ‘Twitter revolution’ in Singapore and share the idea that to remain complacent about the need for advancing further the reformist liberal democratic agenda would be politically undesirable.

fn.p: According to the Urban Dictionary (http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=twitterati) the term ‘twitterati’ refers to ‘the Tweet elite, whose feeds attract thousands of followers and whose 140-character spews capture the attention of the rapt who doggedly monitor them’.

One of the most cited examples comes from Moldova where during the disputed election in 2009, a few local Twitter activists spread news about their ‘flashmob’ and launched a campaign which resulted in huge demonstrations and loud protests (Grossman, 2009; Morozov, 2009b; Mungiu-Pippidi and Munteanu, 2009; van der Zee, 2009; Warlaumont, 2010). Not surprisingly, more recent studies point to the fact that Twitter is being increasingly used as a forum for political deliberation and online messages on Twitter tend to reliably reflect offline political and social sentiment (Cross, 2011; Ifukor, 2010; Murthy, 2011; Tumasjan et al., 2011). Even the mere number of tweets mentioning a party can reflect election results (Cottle, 2011; Tumasjan et al., 2011).
The PAP’s share of votes in the Parliamentary Elections also fell substantially from 65 to 60 per cent since the last election.

Anticipating the expressions of discontent through social networking domains, the Prime Minister had held a Facebook chat shortly before polling day to reach out to netizens in an attempt to listen to them on their home ground (I. Tham, 2011). In the party magazine, the PM noted that the party needed to strengthen its presence in cyberspace and ‘learn to use new media more effectively’.
These were the conditions of access at the time data was collected for this particular study.

It may be mentioned that the Twitter search bar was used after logging into the author’s account so that the algorithms to a certain extent would throw up accounts relevant to the account’s network and tweets.

Hong Lim Park was Singapore’s first privately owned garden. In 2000, it was designated by the government as the venue of the Speaker’s Corner. It is the only venue where demonstrations may be held. Citizens who wish to use the park for public gatherings have to register with the National Parks department.
